I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

So, I'm of the opinion that the church has subtly adapted to the 21st century, but it ain't as rigid as it used to be. Growing up, it was all about Sunday mass, with cute little dresses, matching shoes, and purses. I'd see most of my private school friends there on weekends. But now, it's different. They've introduced a 'teenage mass,' cutting it down to 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, even in their beachwear. Families are coming in late, and at morning masses, you see folks in jeans and khakis. It's more relaxed, but I'm not aware of the church's politics, so that's all I've got. As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I think it's a matter of individual choice and genetics. Marriage, for them or any other faith, wouldn't change that. The problem's in the genes, not in the church's rules or lack thereof. The church could've done more to address this, but I don't think it's entirely their fault.

Alright, let me see, I'm really for gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's something that's been proven to be more biological than sociological. So, denying people rights based on something they have no control over seems kind of inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think politics or government should have a say in this. It's not even something that should be on a state level; it's a personal, household level. My neighborhood, for instance, has two or three openly gay couples living there, not married because they're not allowed to. But they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs down the street like anyone else. And with Bush trying to play God and interpret marriage the way he wants, it's just ridiculous.

I mean, I think it's something that's been proven to be a biological predisposition. I've read and heard from numerous publications that it's something you might be predisposed to being a homosexual, not something that's solely sociological. Like growing up with lots of sisters and a single father could influence it, but it's not the only factor.

But other than the obvious, I think maybe it's because marriage is something that, if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can just run off to Las Vegas and do it without telling anyone. But if two gay people want to do it, it's going to make the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal, private thing, not something in the public domain or national and federal domain.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. If you're talking about harmful stuff, like wanting to blow something up or shoot someone, someone's gonna notice. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no privacy issue because it's something they were given access to. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Um, I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now, it's just about proving our global dominance, and maybe even settling old scores. George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein might have played a role. If the original intent was to give a fair political system to a country under a tyrant, it was a just cause. But over time, I think our objectives have become murky, like we're still at war just to prove we can be at war. We're not ready to admit defeat, and we're spending billions of dollars on a war that's gone on too long. We've been neglecting our own economy, our own citizens' well-being, and it's not sustainable. I mean, they're spending billions and billions, and there are more pressing issues at home, like poverty and infrastructure, that we should be funding instead. Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

I'm still undecided about the nuptial union debate. See, it's a delicate dance, balancing the separation of church and state with the sanctity of marriage.   I mean, if the government can't distinguish between a holy union and a civil one, then why should we let them dictate how we define love?   So, if two people are legally bound, shouldn't we just call it a civil union?   It's a union of two individuals, no more, no less.   And if all states can reach a sensible consensus, then let's push for federal recognition, but a constitutional ban on gay marriage? That's as absurd as amending our founding document for a fling.   It just doesn't warrant such a grand gesture.   So, no. I'm not convinced.

Hmm, I gotta say, I don't buy that. Let me break it down for you. You see, Myspace is meant for public consumption, right? It's like a digital bulletin board for everyone to see, whether it's your peers or not. If school officials want to check up on what students are up to, they've got every right to do so, especially if it's for the greater good. Now, I'm not saying they should go snooping for no reason, but if they find something that could save lives or make the school safer, I think they should be allowed to do their job. It's a responsibility of the school system to keep students safe. I mean, if they find out about students partying or doing drugs, that's their job, right? They're there to keep us safe, not to spy on us. But if it helps make the school a better place, then I'm all for it. The same goes for the police. Parents send their kids to school expecting a safe environment. Sure, we do drills and practice for lockdowns. That's part of making the school safer. So, if school officials are doing the same, I think they're just trying to keep us safe. They're not invading our privacy, they're just doing their job.

At first, I was all in. I was deeply affected by the World Trade Center attacks, and I was ready to unleash hell over there.
But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.

I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

So, I'm of the opinion that the church has subtly adapted to the 21st century, but it ain't as rigid as it used to be. Growing up, it was all about Sunday mass, with cute little dresses, matching shoes, and purses. I'd see most of my private school friends there on weekends. But now, it's different. They've introduced a 'teenage mass,' cutting it down to 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, even in their beachwear. Families are coming in late, and at morning masses, you see folks in jeans and khakis. It's more relaxed, but I'm not aware of the church's politics, so that's all I've got. As for the accusations against Catholic priests, I think it's a matter of individual choice and genetics. Marriage, for them or any other faith, wouldn't change that. The problem's in the genes, not in the church's rules or lack thereof. The church could've done more to address this, but I don't think it's entirely their fault.

Alright, let me see, I'm really for gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's something that's been proven to be more biological than sociological. So, denying people rights based on something they have no control over seems kind of inhumane to me. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think politics or government should have a say in this. It's not even something that should be on a state level; it's a personal, household level. My neighborhood, for instance, has two or three openly gay couples living there, not married because they're not allowed to. But they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs down the street like anyone else. And with Bush trying to play God and interpret marriage the way he wants, it's just ridiculous.

I mean, I think it's something that's been proven to be a biological predisposition. I've read and heard from numerous publications that it's something you might be predisposed to being a homosexual, not something that's solely sociological. Like growing up with lots of sisters and a single father could influence it, but it's not the only factor.

But other than the obvious, I think maybe it's because marriage is something that, if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can just run off to Las Vegas and do it without telling anyone. But if two gay people want to do it, it's going to make the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal, private thing, not something in the public domain or national and federal domain.

No, no.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. If you're talking about harmful stuff, like wanting to blow something up or shoot someone, someone's gonna notice. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no privacy issue because it's something they were given access to. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Um, I feel like the war has dragged on far too long. Initially, the purpose seemed noble: to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've lost sight of that original goal. Now, it's just about proving our global dominance, and maybe even settling old scores. George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein might have played a role. If the original intent was to give a fair political system to a country under a tyrant, it was a just cause. But over time, I think our objectives have become murky, like we're still at war just to prove we can be at war. We're not ready to admit defeat, and we're spending billions of dollars on a war that's gone on too long. We've been neglecting our own economy, our own citizens' well-being, and it's not sustainable. I mean, they're spending billions and billions, and there are more pressing issues at home, like poverty and infrastructure, that we should be funding instead. Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

I mean, anytime you put information on the internet, you're essentially opening yourself up to a wider audience. And if I'm being honest, I think that's a bit unnerving.

It's tough, you know? You can't realistically have one person watching everyone's profiles all day to prevent something like this. I don't know, though. It depends on the situation. Maybe they were looking for evidence of something, or maybe they were just randomly browsing and happened to stumble upon something.

I mean, I don't have a Myspace myself, but I do have a Facebook. It bothers me that there are people out there who can find out a lot about me just by looking at my profile. I've seen something on TV where a guy was able to find a girl's screen name and talk to her on instant messenger in just a few minutes. That's a bit scary.

I don't think I'd meet up with someone like that, but I've had people in my classes who I don't recognize but they know who I am from my IM. It's hard because I have to think about my interests, my schedule, even who I'm friends with. It's a tricky balance, you know? I only accept people I know as friends, but you never know who might be looking.

My roommate told me that in high school, some schools actually banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit strange to me. I'm not sure how they had the power to do that.

I don't really know if that's a privacy issue, but I don't think they had the right to tell people they couldn't have Myspace.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

I'm still undecided about the nuptial union debate. See, it's a delicate dance, balancing the separation of church and state with the sanctity of marriage.   I mean, if the government can't distinguish between a holy union and a civil one, then why should we let them dictate how we define love?   So, if two people are legally bound, shouldn't we just call it a civil union?   It's a union of two individuals, no more, no less.   And if all states can reach a sensible consensus, then let's push for federal recognition, but a constitutional ban on gay marriage? That's as absurd as amending our founding document for a fling.   It just doesn't warrant such a grand gesture.   So, no. I'm not convinced.

So I think I don’t think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals so I feel as though it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

Hmm, I gotta say, I don't buy that. Let me break it down for you. You see, Myspace is meant for public consumption, right? It's like a digital bulletin board for everyone to see, whether it's your peers or not. If school officials want to check up on what students are up to, they've got every right to do so, especially if it's for the greater good. Now, I'm not saying they should go snooping for no reason, but if they find something that could save lives or make the school safer, I think they should be allowed to do their job. It's a responsibility of the school system to keep students safe. I mean, if they find out about students partying or doing drugs, that's their job, right? They're there to keep us safe, not to spy on us. But if it helps make the school a better place, then I'm all for it. The same goes for the police. Parents send their kids to school expecting a safe environment. Sure, we do drills and practice for lockdowns. That's part of making the school safer. So, if school officials are doing the same, I think they're just trying to keep us safe. They're not invading our privacy, they're just doing their job.

The war

At first, I was all in. I was deeply affected by the World Trade Center attacks, and I was ready to unleash hell over there.
But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.

I reckon the Catholic Church could use some tweaking in a few ways, you know?
They've been chatting about their dwindling flock, and I think it's because they're not too accepting, you see?
Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control—these are just a few examples.
They've got strong views, no doubt, but they're a bit antiquated, if you get my drift.
I think if they embraced a more contemporary outlook, they wouldn't be so worried about losing their followers.
I've heard of folks distancing themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues.
People aren't aligning with their views on certain matters these days.
So I guess they think the Church is a bit off on these topics.
I mean, the Church's anti-abortion stance might make some uncomfortable, especially if they believe in it.
And the same goes for gay marriage—if you feel strongly about it, you might not want to follow a church that's against it.
I don't see why they can't have female priests or let priests get married, but then again, I'm not sure if that would've changed what happened.
I mean, it's hard to say what they'd do differently if they could marry or have women priests.
But I'm not convinced it would've made a significant difference.
I just don't get why priests can't have a family life like everyone else.
They say they're married to God, but everyone else has both work and family life, so why can't they?

Well, I'm not against gay marriage, you know. I mean, who am I to judge? Whether someone is born that way, or whatever, I don't think it's something people choose. So, I think it's unfair to hold them responsible for their sexual orientation. It's like saying a man and a woman can marry, but not two people of the same sex. That's wrong, in my opinion. I haven't really given the topic much thought, but I'd say that's just not right. It's not a choice, like they don't have a say in how they are. I was born straight, and someone else might be born gay. It doesn't seem like a conscious decision they should be held accountable for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, or even a moral one. It's not about our country's security or anything like that. It's just that they're out of place when they try to interject in people's lives. And that's just who they are. It's like their birthright, and they shouldn't be punished for it. That's all I have to say about that.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Why? Well, let me put it simply, there's no compelling reason not to. Some people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional heterosexual families, but it's just not that straightforward. Truth be told, there are so many different aspects to this issue that it's foolish to compare it to anything else. It's like two sides of the same coin, no matter how much you try to flip it, they're still the same face. It's not like one is heads and the other tails, they're just different sides of the same reality. And there are so many civil rights implications at play here, like property taxes and healthcare. If you're in a gay couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be by your side in your time of need, because they're not technically family. I mean, if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone, it seems silly to deny them that right. Plus, scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates as heterosexual couples in terms of relationship satisfaction. It's just a relationship, plain and simple. And let's not forget, the people who want to get married aren't asking for the religious sanctification of their union. They just want a legal document that recognizes their commitment, a marriage certificate. If there's no religious involvement, then how can that be an issue? I can't comprehend why people like Catholics would object to this based on their religious beliefs, especially when they're not even directly involved. If you're allowing civil unions, then why not allow marriage? It's like segregation all over again, separate but unequal. Homosexual relationships are no different in terms of community involvement or parenting skills. Children of gay couples are just as well-adjusted as children of heterosexual couples. And the federal government should be at the forefront of this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state. But, of course, President Bush has his own strong views on this matter, much like his stance on abortion and stem cell research. He seems to be driven by moral reasons, but morality is subjective and varies from person to person. The government should not enforce the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. It's hypocritical to let laws be made that enforce religious standards on everyone, especially considering the recent controversies about the pledge of allegiance. Many people are opposed to gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but that's just not accurate. The American Psychological Association has stated this is untrue. If only people listened to institutions that do actual research instead of relying on popular opinion or their local community's beliefs.

Now, let me start by saying that I happen to be working at a hospital pharmacy this summer. And while it's true that not all illegal drugs are beneficial, there's a certain irony in that. You see, the very fact that something is illegal doesn't mean it lacks use, especially in the medical field. I'm talking about opioids like oxycodone, vicodin, percocets—you name it. They're controlled substances because they have their benefits, yet we use them all the time. And the thing about marijuana, well, it's not the same as alcohol. While both can be abused, marijuana, when used responsibly, is a different beast. I believe you could gradually make it legal, but first, you've got to remove that taboo around marijuana. Too many people have a skewed image of it, thinking it's as harmful as heroin or cocaine. But I'm telling you, it's not. If we can get past that image, people might start using it responsibly, and certainly for medicinal purposes. But right now, with that stigma? It's a no-go.

Listen, putting stuff online is public. People can see it, and it can color their opinions of you. The internet is a huge public forum, and if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. The school isn't the one who got the warning, someone else did. They have to act on it because if something happens, they could have prevented it. But sometimes, people just mess around, and you don't know what to take seriously. Like that time at school; something happened, and someone overheard someone else saying something, then called it in. When they found out who said it, they checked their Facebook, and it turned out they were just joking. But in that situation, it became serious. When you put something out there, it's not private. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or take seriously. I don't think school officials should friend their students on social media and snoop around. I don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend students. That's not appropriate. I wouldn't want to see my residents' wild nights out on Facebook, not because I care, but because it's not my business. It's not my place to know or to act on it. I respect their privacy, and I don't need that connection.

Right now, that money is being spent on a war that's lost its cause. I think it's time to step back and let the locals handle it.

You see, they didn’t legalize it, no, not by a long shot. They decriminalized it, yeah. That means they knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—you know, get cited and be on your way, rather than getting booked, arrested, and dragged into court. And sure, if you get caught, it may show up on your record, affecting job prospects and such. But you know, the stigma of a drug charge looms large, even if it's just weed. Decriminalization doesn't erase that.

Imagine the cost, though. Arresting, booking, and processing people, not to mention the trials, public defenders, judges, and court fees. It adds up to a hefty bill for the state. In places strapped for cash, they just can't afford to make that concession, even if it might free up some money for other needs. But in a place like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, it's a different story. Decriminalizing it could mean more funds for public education and social programs.

Now, I’m not saying we should make it legal to walk around smoking it everywhere. That would be a whole different kettle of fish. It's still taboo in many places, and the thought of seeing people openly smoking weed on the streets might be uncomfortable for some. And then there's the issue of lifestyle impact. Sure, alcohol can mess with your driving skills, but marijuana often affects people's lifestyle more than just their decision-making abilities.

Every person reacts differently, you know? Some can handle anything, others know how to moderate, and some just can't. So, it's hard to generalize about how these substances affect people. But make no mistake, they all have their adverse effects.

But looking back, I think we let our emotions cloud our judgment. We didn't think about the long-term consequences and just went in unprepared. We were like a bull in a china shop, causing more chaos than it was worth.
I’ve since changed my stance. I don't believe our presence there has made any real difference. They’re so caught up in their own conflicts, they can’t focus on us. It's like we’re just a distraction.
I've lost all interest in what happens over there. I mean, they’re just fighting amongst themselves, so why should we care? They can’t even get along with themselves.
We just went in there with our emotions high and no real plan. We were driven by anger and revenge, more than anything else. We should have been more rational about what we were getting into. We couldn’t have just allowed them to get away with what they did.
I still think we had no choice but to go to war, but we should have been better prepared. We had no clear plan, no unity of purpose. We just went in with emotions, and that’s what we ended up creating.
I really don’t think we’re the ones to change those people. They’re always going to be like that, and I don’t think we’re making enough progress to justify our stay.
We need to consider leaving, and we need to do it soon. We can’t stay over there forever. It’s hurting us more than it’s helping.
So, that’s where I stand.
